definition: predestined fate (Buddhism)
to rob/to plunder/to seize by force/to coerce/calamity/abbr. for kalpa 劫波[jie2 bo1]
frequently/repeatedly
number/figure/several/CL:個|个[ge4]
to count/to count as/to regard as/to enumerate (sb's shortcomings)
Destiny is inexorable, there is no fleeing it (idiom). Your doom is at hand.

sentences.english: But, when the hunter falls in love with prey, his inexorable doom often starts accordingly.
sentences.chinese: 但是，當獵人愛上獵物的時候，他的劫數常因此肇始。

sentences.english: It immediately gave Artest a sense of doom.
sentences.chinese: 這直接給了阿泰難逃劫數的感覺。

sentences.english: If the two forward combination Shuangjian, Belgium Jieshuo will not be able to escape.
sentences.chinese: 這兩名前鋒如果雙劍合璧，比利時將劫數難逃。

sentences.english: Everything is more beautiful because we're doomed.
sentences.chinese: 萬物變得更美因爲註定劫數難逃。

sentences.english: Why do I love this into a disaster unscathed.
sentences.chinese: 爲什麼愛在我這裏變成一場災難的劫數。

sentences.english: But today, we cannot escape our doomed fate.
Touble is a block-up of those who are persueing for happiness forever.
sentences.chinese: 煩惱，永遠是尋找幸福的人命中的劫數。

sentences.english: I know at a glance, he is my plunders the.
sentences.chinese: 我一眼就知道，他就是我的劫數了。

definition: virtue has its rewards (idiom); one good turn deserves another
(Buddhism) retribution/karma
fate/destiny/one's lot
omniscient
to transmit Buddhist teaching/chakram or chakka (throwing disk)
evil has its retribution (idiom); to suffer the consequences of one's bad deeds/sow the wind and reap the whirlwind (Hosea 8:7)
many men, a great force (idiom); many hands provide great strength/There is safety in numbers.
the world of the living
illusion (Buddhism)/pipe dream

Feast at Hongmen/(fig.) banquet set up with the aim of murdering a guest/refers to a famous episode in 206 BC when future Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1] escaped attempted murder by his rival Xiang Yu 項羽|项羽[Xiang4 Yu3]
to think for oneself and act accordingly (idiom); to act on one's own initiative
lit. to return the jade annulus to Zhao (idiom); fig. to return something intact to its rightful owner
extinct
annihilation (of soul, Sanskrit uccheda)
to watch the fires burning across the river/to delay entering the fray until all others have been exhausted by fighting amongst themselves (idiom)
lit. to upend heaven and earth (idiom)/fig. to change the course of events/to turn things around
